prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Reglet and Furniture

’Twas rickety dusk, and the reglet quills
   Went snicker-snap beside the chair;
All fondle-frilled were the couchen frills,
   And the furnitroves taumed in air.

“Beware the Furnisnatch, my child!
   The ottomutch that croaks and gnaws!
Beware the whiffling table-wild,
   And shun the clattering claw-drawers!”

He took his splinter-sabre keen;
   Long time the gnarly rogue he sought—
So rested he by a lamp-shade tree,
   And plunged in ponder-thought.

And, as he hummed in moonlit hush,
   The Furnisnatch, with hinges dire,
Came clumping through the carpet-brush,
   Its cushions belching springs of fire!

One—two! One—two! And through and through
   His splinter-sabre whirled crack-smack!
He left it dead, and snagged its head,
   And trundled jubilant back.

“And hast thou quelled the Furnisnatch?
   O bravo, brave regletling boy!
O jiggalump day! Caloop! Calatch!”
   He capered, mad with joy.

’Twas rickety dusk, and the reglet quills
   Went snicker-snap beside the chair;
All fondle-frilled were the couchen frills,
   And the furnitroves taumed in air.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Blued-Screw Shimble

’Twas brizzen dawn, when plimpsy gears  
Did whindle-waltch and weave;  
All flimsy flew the copper spheres,  
And clanksmoke clogged the eave.  

Beware, beware the Blued-Screw twist,  
Its rivet-fangs, its torqueish bite!  
Shun well the gruzzled piston-mist,  
The toggling teeth of night.  

He gripped his polished ratchet bar,  
Long time he scoured the gloam;  
He paused beneath the mantel star  
And hummed a thrumsome pome.  

And as in tangle-thought he stood,  
The Blued-Screw, slick and blue,  
Came skirl-fling through the wobbling wood,  
And stammer-cried “Skra-koo!”  

Click-whack! Click-whack! The ratchet cracked!  
His counter-swing was keen;  
He sheared the head, the coils went slack,  
He wiped his wrenchy sheen.  

“O have you stilled the Blued-Screw dread?  
Come clamp me with your pride!”  
“O gladsome whirr! The screw lies dead!”  
He flang the head inside.  

’Twas brizzen dusk; the plimpsy gears  
Still whindle-waltch and weave;  
No bluer screw in all frontiers,  
Yet torque sings make-believe.
label: high
judge_raw:

<C5_think>Final stanza echoes opening with ≥2 repeated content words/phrases: "’Twas brizzen" (like ’Twas brillig), "plimpsy gears", "whindle-waltch and weave" repeated, serving as a ring composition.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present: stanza 2 repeats "Beware, beware the Blued-Screw twist" and cautionary phrases about its "rivet-fangs" and "torquish bite".</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation occurs in stanza 3: protagonist grips ratchet bar, scours the gloam, pauses and contemplates ("hummed a thrumsome pome") before encounter.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter clearly described in stanza 4: Blued-Screw appears, described with action and vocalization ("skirl-fling", "stammer-cried"), indicating confrontation.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action is in stanza 5: "Click-whack! Click-whack!" the ratchet cracks, he shears the head; clear resolution of the central tension.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration in stanza 6 and 7: protagonist is congratulated and proud, "gladsome whirr", "screw lies dead", "flang the head inside" indicate successful return.</C10_think>

<C19_think>Syllable counts approximate Jabberwocky style: longer lines ~8-9 syllables, shorter lines ~5-7 syllables, consistent pattern in all quatrains.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme endings in (2,4) positions are varied with no exact end word repeated more than twice (excluding ring echo), showing good variety.</C20_think>

<C23_think>Poem clearly addresses similar topic to "Jabberwocky": a named adversary-creature (Blued-Screw) confronted and slain by protagonist, matching theme of encounter with an invented creature.</C23_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmuration Over Stubble

’Twas duskle-dim, and prickly ricks
   Lay bristle-bound and bare;
The swizzle-swarms in wimpling flicks
   Spun flurries through the air.

Beware the Quorkwing, farmborn child,
   The bluster-breasted sweep!
Beware the razzle-rustlewild,
   And shun the shabble-steep!

He grasped his whorling willow-spar,
   Long time the foe to find;
He lingered where the stubbles are,
   In broodsome autumn mind.

And, while in bruckle thought he roamed,
   The Quorkwing, with a cry,
Came swurging, swizzling, skyward-combed,
   Dark whirl against the sky!

Snick-snark! Snick-snark! His willow-spar
   Went flashing swift and keen;
He smote it thrice from nock to nar,
   And left it slither-clean.

“O hast thou quelled the Quorkwing’s flite?
   Come prance, my plucky sprout!”
He strode him home in starry night
   With torely triumph shout.

’Twas duskle-dim, and prickly ricks
   Lay bristle-bound and bare;
The swizzle-swarms in wimpling flicks
   Wove murmurs through the air.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "Murmuration Over Stubble" present and before any stanza, non-empty</C1_think>
<C2_think>7 stanzas total; all are quatrains (4 lines each); stanza count within 5–8; meets criteria</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines generally alternate longer and shorter patterns with ~2 or more content-word difference in 5 or more of 7 stanzas (≥60%)—ballad meter echoed</C3_think>
<C4_think>In 5 or more stanzas, lines 2 and 4 rhyme or slant rhyme (e.g., bare/air, sweep/steep, cry/sky, keen/clean, sprout/shout, bare/air); no AABB pattern dominance—meets rhyme pattern</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza repeats several content words/phrases from first stanza ("’Twas duskle-dim," "prickly ricks," "bristle-bound and bare," "swizzle-swarms in wimpling flicks")—strong ring composition</C5_think>
<C6_think>Second stanza contains explicit warning/admonition: "Beware the Quorkwing, farmborn child," with further warnings, fulfilling admonition criterion</C6_think>

<C9_think>Decisive action present: stanza 5 "Snick-snark! Snick-snark!" onomatopoeia, "His willow-spar went flashing swift and keen," "He smote it thrice" and "left it slither-clean," depicts slaying or resolution</C9_think>

<C11_think>At least 8 distinct coinages: duskle-dim, prickly ricks, swizzle-swarms, wimpling flicks, Quorkwing, bluster-breasted, razzle-rustlewild, shabble-steep, whorling willow-spar, bruckle thought, swurging, swizzling, slither-clean, torely (at least some counted as coinages); confidently ≥8 distinct coinages</C11_think>
